channel.title: Interesting Links - Discuss @ Bootstrapped.fm
channel.description: Topics in the 'Interesting Links' category Find something really great other Bootstrappers could learn from? Post it up.

item.title: Conducting customer interviews
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
In the last few months, Liz Painter did some interviews on our behalf with Feature Upvote customers.

The process went well, so I invited Liz to write up her process for conducting customer interviews for our blog.

Feature Upvote

Conducting Customer Interviews - Feature Upvote

A straightforward way for product teams to interview customers - and gain better product insights.

It is detailed and written by someone who conducts lots of customer interviews and has a systematic approach for doing them.

1 post - 1 participant

Read full topic
item.source: Conducting customer interviews

item.title: My appearance on the “First 10” podcast
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
The “First 10” podcast has an interesting premise:

The First 10 Podcast interviews business builders on their First 10 Customers - who they were, how they found them, and what effect they had on their business, so that you can learn what worked, and what didn’t.

I had the opportunity to be a guest on the most recent episode. I talked about how I got the first 10 post-acquisition customers for Saber Feedback:

Conor McCarthy

The First 10 Podcast #19 - Steve McLeod — Conor McCarthy

The First 10 Podcast interviews business builders on their First 10 Customers - who they were, how they found them, how to talk to them, and what effect they had on their business, so that you can learn what worked, and what didn’t. From founders to...

2 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic
item.source: My appearance on the “First 10” podcast

item.title: My setup for using Twitter without hating it
item.dc:creator: ivm
item.description:
In October, I was getting back to my independent projects after a long sabbatical. I wanted to start building my new app in public and keep in touch with other indie makers, but almost all of this happens on Twitter. Before I semi-abandoned this platform multiple times because it was too energy-consuming.

So I tried various approaches and ended up with a whole article on how to use Twitter in a way that does not affect your well-being:

qotoqot.com

My setup for using Twitter without hating it

How to get only the good parts of this infamous social network

I also made a small tool to measure the tweeting speed of your Twitter lists and their members: Listometer

Hope it will be useful!

5 posts - 4 participants

Read full topic
item.source: My setup for using Twitter without hating it

item.title: Recommended: SureSwift's "Founder's Squad" newsletter
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
I interviewed Kevin McArdle of SureSwift Capital in episode 146.

Kevin has a monthly email for founders and I highly recommend it. You can sign up here: Join the Founder’s Squad!

It is typically full of useful tips you can apply to your business. The tips come from the system that Kevin’s team uses to run 30+ SaaS companies in their portfolio.

item.title: Changing the way of building web apps!
item.dc:creator: andressb
item.description:
Hey bootstrappers,

As some of you might know we’ve been working on Scalab for a while already and I’m very excited to share these updates:

We decided to change the name to funkLang.
funkLang it’s a new FrontEnd framework that combines visual and programmatic workflows that allow designers and developers to work together; think about a mix of Figma, React, and Webflow.

We started to send the beta invites last month, and we are planning to officially launch in January.
Please drop your feedback, opinion, doubts, or any comment here or to andres@funklang.com.

hero600×634 848 KB

5 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Changing the way of building web apps!

item.title: Kickstarting the cold emailing engine for bootstrapped businesses
item.dc:creator: ashwin.r
item.description:
I have built one bootstrapped tech business and sold it. I am now running a venture-backed (seed-funded) data science company that is cash-flow positive and does not need growth rounds to scale.
We have been cashflow positive for 18 months now.

The secret is figuring out a channel that works and then scaling it. It’s not about finding 10 channels but 1 or 2 and wringing every piece of efficiency out of it.

For us, cold emailing has worked wonderfully. It’s a zero-waste, low-cost approach because you choose the targets. So every response is an MQL.

I wrote an ebook and how this channel has worked for us and why it is replicable.

To give you an idea, in the last 18 months, we have earned over $300K in deals that came through this channel (with a marketing investment of under $20,000).

I am writing this as a way to give hope to bootstrapped entrepreneurs (especially the tech ones) that cold emailing is not bad after all, if you know how to run and scale it the right way.

As a new user, I cannot post links here to the ebook. But if you’d like it, I can respond as a comment.

3 posts - 3 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Kickstarting the cold emailing engine for bootstrapped businesses

item.description:

23 rules to run a software startup with minimum hassle

Over the last 5 years of bootstrapping, I’ve tried a lot of things, and discovered there are many ways to create hassle for yourself that wastes time and energy and distracts you from building value in your business. This is my second post on lessons...

The important thing to remember is the “with minimum hassle” clause in the title!

item.title: Zero to Sold: The Bootstrapper's Compendium
item.dc:creator: arvidkahl
item.description:
I recently published a 25,000-word compendium called “Zero to Sold”. I’ve written this guide over the last few months, in parallel to the articles and newsletters I have been publishing.

Zero to Sold is a compendium of all the stages of a bootstrapped business and the challenges you will encounter along the way. It contains stories and experiences from my time at FeedbackPanda, from the humble beginnings to the details of our exit (and the unchartered wilds beyond).

Every week, I will write at least one blog post on a specific subject that represents a section in Zero to Sold. Once the post is published, it will be linked directly from the compendium. That way, the guide will grow over time, adding in-depth articles to the concise and detailed sections of Zero to Sold every week.

Every Friday, I publish the Bootstrapped Founder Newsletter. Every edition contains a link to a poll that allows my subscribers to vote for next week’s article. So if my readers want to make sure I prioritize the articles you care about, they can subscribe to the newsletter and vote for what I should write first. That way, I get subscribers, and they get a real chance at affecting my priorities.

My newsletter is a channel for me to explore new and current topics while delivering stories and insights from my time at FeedbackPanda (and all the failed startups I was in before). I expect to add more sections to Zero to Sold from interesting topics that I find in the bootstrapping community, either through the links that I collect every week or the incredibly insightful conversations I have on Twitter almost every day. Of course, any replies added to this topic will be considered for this as well!

This is my first book. It’s also my first info product, so I am learning a lot about all of this every single day. If you have any suggestions, please reach out to me here, on Twitter, or through the contact form on the blog.

It’s thebootstrappedfounder.com/zero-to-sold/

12 posts - 4 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Zero to Sold: The Bootstrapper's Compendium

item.title: MicroConf USA 2019 talks available for purchase
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
MicroConf’s 2017 videos are available to the public and 2018/2019 are for sale.

Get them here: https://www.microconf.com/growth/past-videos/

The 2019 talks are $99, the 2018 talks are $49, and the talks from 2017 are free.

This is great value for us bootstrappers, and well worth buying.

I believe if you went to the US conference this year, or are going to MicroConf Europe later this year, you can watch all these talks for free.

(I bought the 2019 package myself and am working my way through it.)

1 post - 1 participant

Read full topic
item.source: MicroConf USA 2019 talks available for purchase

item.title: Lee Carter on the Value of Direct Observation of Your Customers
item.dc:creator: skmurphy
item.description:
A Q&A with Lee Carter where we explore the value of direct observation of customer environments to complement customer interviews. Lee shares details of a project he worked on where direct observation provided a valuable complement to a basic product specification.

Q: You are a strong advocate for the going onsite to be able to see the customer’s environment and how they operate in it as a complement to customer interviews. Can you tell me a little more about your experience with direct observation?

A: Well, the short answer is that observation will give you insights that you won’t get from just interviewing someone.
[…]

3 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Lee Carter on the Value of Direct Observation of Your Customers

item.title: Should you make your SaaS self-service?
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
Here’s an article we recently added to our site, comparing the “sales call only” approach vs the “self-service only” approach:

We look at the different approaches of UserVoice and Trello. Both companies are successful: Atlassian paid $425 million for Trello, making it Atlassian’s most expensive acquisition to date. UserVoice, meanwhile, counts companies like Microsoft among its user base.

However, UserVoice and Trello onboard clients in very different ways.

Read the whole article.

1 post - 1 participant

Read full topic
item.source: Should you make your SaaS self-service?

item.title: The "Windup" Strategy
item.dc:creator: SteveMcLeod
item.description:
@ian questions why we in the software industry feel the need to grow fast:

Why does your software company have to grow fast?

Why is building fast assumed when discussing a new software company, regardless of if it’s bootstrapped or VC backed?

Sure, the idea of not growing “VC” levels of fast has been baked into bootstrapping software companies from the start. But can we push it further?

Read the whole article here: https://thermostat.io/the-windup-strategy

4 posts - 4 participants

Read full topic
item.source: The "Windup" Strategy
